an5.67:1.1.pli: “Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā pañca dhamme bhāveti, pañca dhamme bahulīkaroti, tassa dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
an5.67:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, any monk or nun who develops and cultivates five qualities can expect one of two results:

an5.67:1.2.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā.
an5.67:1.2.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.

an5.67:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu chandasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti,
an5.67:2.2.eng: A mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort …

an5.67:2.3.eng: A mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort …

an5.67:2.4.eng: A mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort …

an5.67:2.5.eng: A mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort.

an5.67:2.6.eng: And the fifth is sheer vigor.

an5.67:2.7.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā ime pañca dhamme bhāveti, ime pañca dhamme bahulīkaroti, tassa dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
an5.67:2.7.eng: Any monk or nun who develops and cultivates these five qualities can expect one of two results:

an5.67:2.8.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā”ti.
an5.67:2.8.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”

an5.68:1.1.pli: “Pubbevāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sambodhā anabhisambuddho bodhisattova samāno pañca dhamme bhāvesiṃ, pañca dhamme bahulīkāsiṃ.
an5.68:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still not awake but intent on awakening—I developed and cultivated five things.

an5.68:1.3.eng: The basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort …

an5.68:1.4.eng: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort …

an5.68:1.5.eng: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort …

an5.68:1.6.eng: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort.

an5.68:1.7.eng: And the fifth is sheer vigor.

an5.68:1.8.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ ussoḷhipañcamānaṃ dhammānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā yassa yassa abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyassa dhammassa cittaṃ abhininnāmesiṃ abhiññāsacchikiriyāya,
an5.68:1.8.eng: When I had developed and cultivated these five things, with vigor as fifth,

an5.68:1.9.pli: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇiṃ sati sati āyatane.
an5.68:1.9.eng: I extended the mind to realize by insight each and every thing that can be realized by insight; and I was capable of realizing those things, since each and every one was within range.

an5.68:2.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhiṃ: ‘anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhaveyyaṃ …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteyyan’ti,
an5.68:2.1.eng: If I wished: ‘May I multiply myself and become one again … controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.’

an5.68:2.2.pli: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇiṃ sati sati āyatane.
an5.68:2.2.eng: I was capable of realizing it, since each and every one is within range.

an5.68:3.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhiṃ …pe… ‘āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyan’ti,
an5.68:3.1.eng: If I wished: … ‘May I realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

an5.68:3.2.pli: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇiṃ sati sati āyatane”ti.
an5.68:3.2.eng: I was capable of realizing it, since each and every one is within range.”

an5.69:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattanti.
an5.69:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these five things, when developed and cultivated, lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

an5.69:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asubhānupassī kāye viharati, āhāre paṭikūlasaññī, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññī, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī, maraṇasaññā kho panassa ajjhattaṃ sūpaṭṭhitā hoti.
an5.69:2.2.eng: A mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions, and has well established the perception of their own death.

an5.69:2.3.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattantī”ti.
an5.69:2.3.eng: These five things, when developed and cultivated, lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.”

an5.7:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, sentient beings are mostly charmed by sensual pleasures.

an5.7:1.2.pli: Asitabyābhaṅgiṃ, bhikkhave, kulaputto ohāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti, ‘saddhāpabbajito kulaputto’ti alaṃvacanāya.
an5.7:1.2.eng: When a gentleman has abandoned the scythe and flail and gone forth from the lay life to homelessness, they’re qualified to be called ‘a faithful renunciate from a good family’.

an5.7:1.4.pli: Labbhā, bhikkhave, yobbanena kāmā te ca kho yādisā vā tādisā vā.
an5.7:1.4.eng: Because a youth can get sensual pleasures of this kind or that.

an5.7:1.5.pli: Ye ca, bhikkhave, hīnā kāmā ye ca majjhimā kāmā ye ca paṇītā kāmā, sabbe kāmā ‘kāmā’tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchanti.
an5.7:1.5.eng: Now, all sensual pleasures are just reckoned as ‘sensual pleasures’, regardless of whether they’re inferior, average, or superior.

an5.7:1.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, daharo kumāro mando uttānaseyyako dhātiyā pamādamanvāya kaṭṭhaṃ vā kaṭhalaṃ vā mukhe āhareyya.
an5.7:1.6.eng: Suppose there was a little baby boy who, because of his nursemaid’s negligence, puts a stick or stone in his mouth.

an5.7:1.7.pli: Tamenaṃ dhāti sīghaṃ sīghaṃ manasi kareyya;
an5.7:1.7.eng: The nursemaid would very quickly notice

an5.7:1.8.pli: sīghaṃ sīghaṃ manasi karitvā sīghaṃ sīghaṃ āhareyya.
an5.7:1.8.eng: and try to take it out.

an5.7:1.9.pli: No ce sakkuṇeyya sīghaṃ sīghaṃ āharituṃ, vāmena hatthena sīsaṃ pariggahetvā dakkhiṇena hatthena vaṅkaṅguliṃ karitvā salohitampi āhareyya.
an5.7:1.9.eng: If that didn’t work, she’d cradle his head with her left hand, and take it out using a hooked finger of her right hand, even if it drew blood.

an5.7:1.11.eng: I admit she’d know, ‘This will distress the child,

an5.7:1.13.pli: Karaṇīyañca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, dhātiyā atthakāmāya hitesiniyā anukampikāya, anukampaṃ upādāya.
an5.7:1.13.eng: Still, it should be done by a nursemaid who wants what’s best for him, out of kindness and sympathy.

an5.7:1.14.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, so kumāro vuddho hoti alaṃpañño, anapekkhā dāni, bhikkhave, dhāti tasmiṃ kumāre hoti:
an5.7:1.14.eng: And when the boy has grown up and has enough sense, his nursemaid would not be concerned about him, thinking:

an5.7:1.15.eng: ‘The boy can look after himself. He won’t be negligent.’

an5.7:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yāvakīvañca bhikkhuno saddhāya akataṃ hoti kusalesu dhammesu, hiriyā akataṃ hoti kusalesu dhammesu, ottappena akataṃ hoti kusalesu dhammesu, vīriyena akataṃ hoti kusalesu dhammesu, paññāya akataṃ hoti kusalesu dhammesu, anurakkhitabbo tāva me so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu hoti.
an5.7:2.1.eng: In the same way, I still need to look after a mendicant who hasn’t finished developing faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom regarding skillful qualities.

an5.7:2.2.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno saddhāya kataṃ hoti kusalesu dhammesu, hiriyā kataṃ hoti kusalesu dhammesu, ottappena kataṃ hoti kusalesu dhammesu, vīriyena kataṃ hoti kusalesu dhammesu, paññāya kataṃ hoti kusalesu dhammesu, anapekkho dānāhaṃ, bhikkhave, tasmiṃ bhikkhusmiṃ homi:
an5.7:2.2.eng: But when a mendicant has finished developing faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom regarding skillful qualities, I need not be concerned, thinking:

an5.7:2.3.eng: ‘They can look after themselves. They won’t be negligent.’”

an5.70:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā āsavānaṃ khayāya saṃvattanti.
an5.70:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these five things, when developed and cultivated, lead to the ending of defilements.

an5.70:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asubhānupassī kāye viharati, āhāre paṭikūlasaññī, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññī, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī, maraṇasaññā kho panassa ajjhattaṃ sūpaṭṭhitā hoti.
an5.70:1.3.eng: A mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions, and has well established the perception of their own death.

an5.70:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā āsavānaṃ khayāya saṃvattantī”ti.
an5.70:1.4.eng: These five things, when developed and cultivated, lead to the ending of defilements.”

an5.70:2.1.pli: Dve ca saññā dve vaḍḍhī ca,

an5.71:0.3.eng: Freedom of Heart is the Fruit (1st)

an5.71:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā cetovimuttiphalā ca honti cetovimuttiphalānisaṃsā ca, paññāvimuttiphalā ca honti paññāvimuttiphalānisaṃsā ca.
an5.71:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these five things, when developed and cultivated, have freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as their fruit and benefit.

an5.71:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asubhānupassī kāye viharati, āhāre paṭikūlasaññī, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññī, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī, maraṇasaññā kho panassa ajjhattaṃ sūpaṭṭhitā hoti.
an5.71:2.2.eng: A mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions, and has well established the perception of their own death.

an5.71:2.3.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā cetovimuttiphalā ca honti cetovimuttiphalānisaṃsā ca, paññāvimuttiphalā ca honti paññāvimuttiphalānisaṃsā ca.
an5.71:2.3.eng: These five things, when developed and cultivated, have freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as their fruit and benefit.

an5.71:2.4.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cetovimutto ca hoti paññāvimutto ca hoti—
an5.71:2.4.eng: When a mendicant has freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom,

an5.71:2.5.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu ukkhittapaligho itipi, saṅkiṇṇaparikho itipi, abbūḷhesiko itipi, niraggaḷo itipi, ariyo pannaddhajo pannabhāro visaṃyutto itipi’.
an5.71:2.5.eng: such a mendicant is one who is called ‘one who has lifted the cross-bar’, ‘one who has filled in the moat’, ‘one who has pulled up the pillar’, ‘one who is unimpeded’, and also ‘a noble one with banner lowered and burden dropped, detached’.

an5.71:3.1.eng: And how has a mendicant lifted the cross-bar?

an5.71:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno avijjā pahīnā hoti ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
an5.71:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has given up ignorance, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.

an5.71:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ukkhittapaligho hoti.
an5.71:3.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant has lifted the cross-bar.

an5.71:4.1.eng: And how has a mendicant filled in the moat?

an5.71:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ponobhaviko jātisaṃsāro pahīno hoti ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo.
an5.71:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has given up transmigrating through births in future lives, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.

an5.71:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saṅkiṇṇaparikho hoti.
an5.71:4.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant has filled in the moat.

an5.71:5.1.eng: And how has a mendicant pulled up the pillar?

an5.71:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno taṇhā pahīnā hoti ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
an5.71:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has given up craving, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.

an5.71:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abbūḷhesiko hoti.
an5.71:5.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant has pulled up the pillar.

an5.71:6.1.eng: And how is a mendicant unimpeded?

an5.71:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pañcorambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni pahīnāni honti ucchinnamūlāni tālāvatthukatāni anabhāvaṅkatāni āyatiṃ anuppādadhammāni.
an5.71:6.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has given up the five lower fetters, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future.

an5.71:6.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu niraggaḷo hoti.
an5.71:6.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is unimpeded.

an5.71:7.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyo pannaddhajo pannabhāro visaṃyutto hoti?
an5.71:7.1.eng: And how is a mendicant a noble one with with banner lowered and burden dropped, detached?

an5.71:7.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno asmimāno pahīno hoti ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo.
an5.71:7.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has given up the conceit ‘I am’, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.

an5.71:7.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyo pannaddhajo pannabhāro visaṃyutto hotī”ti.
an5.71:7.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is a noble one with banner lowered and burden dropped, detached.”

an5.72:0.3.eng: Freedom of Heart is the Fruit (2nd)

an5.72:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā cetovimuttiphalā ca honti cetovimuttiphalānisaṃsā ca, paññāvimuttiphalā ca honti paññāvimuttiphalānisaṃsā ca.
an5.72:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these five things, when developed and cultivated, have freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as their fruit and benefit.

an5.72:1.3.pli: Aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā—
an5.72:1.3.eng: The perception of impermanence, the perception of suffering in impermanence, the perception of not-self in suffering, the perception of giving up, and the perception of fading away.

an5.72:1.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā cetovimuttiphalā ca honti cetovimuttiphalānisaṃsā ca, paññāvimuttiphalā ca honti paññāvimuttiphalānisaṃsā ca.
an5.72:1.4.eng: These five things, when developed and cultivated, have freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as their fruit and benefit.

an5.72:1.5.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cetovimutto ca hoti paññāvimutto ca—
an5.72:1.5.eng: When a mendicant has freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom,

an5.72:1.6.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu ukkhittapaligho itipi, saṅkiṇṇaparikho itipi, abbūḷhesiko itipi, niraggaḷo itipi, ariyo pannaddhajo pannabhāro visaṃyutto itipi’”.
an5.72:1.6.eng: such a mendicant is one who is called ‘one who has lifted the cross-bar’, ‘one who has filled in the moat’, ‘one who has pulled up the pillar’, ‘one who is unimpeded’, and also ‘a noble one with banner lowered and burden dropped, detached’. …”

an5.72:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno avijjā pahīnā hoti ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.

an5.72:2.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ukkhittapaligho hoti.

an5.72:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ponobhaviko jātisaṃsāro pahīno hoti ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo.

an5.72:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saṅkiṇṇaparikho hoti.

an5.72:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno taṇhā pahīnā hoti ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.

an5.72:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abbūḷhesiko hoti.

an5.72:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pañcorambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni pahīnāni honti ucchinnamūlāni tālāvatthukatāni anabhāvaṅkatāni āyatiṃ anuppādadhammāni.

an5.72:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu niraggaḷo hoti.

an5.72:6.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyo pannaddhajo pannabhāro visaṃyutto hoti?

an5.72:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno asmimāno pahīno hoti ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo.

an5.72:6.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyo pannaddhajo pannabhāro visaṃyutto hotī”ti.

an5.73:0.3.eng: One Who Lives by the Teaching (1st)

an5.73:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an5.73:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an5.73:1.2.eng: “Sir, they speak of ‘one who lives by the teaching’.

an5.73:1.3.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhu dhammavihārī hotī”ti?
an5.73:1.3.eng: How is a mendicant who lives by the teaching defined?”

an5.73:2.1.eng: “Mendicant, take a mendicant who memorizes the teaching—

an5.73:2.2.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ.
an5.73:2.2.eng: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.

an5.73:2.3.pli: So tāya dhammapariyattiyā divasaṃ atināmeti, riñcati paṭisallānaṃ, nānuyuñjati ajjhattaṃ cetosamathaṃ.
an5.73:2.3.eng: They spend too much time studying that teaching. They neglect retreat, and are not committed to internal serenity of heart.

an5.73:2.4.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhu: ‘bhikkhu pariyattibahulo, no dhammavihārī’.
an5.73:2.4.eng: That mendicant is called one who studies a lot, not one who lives by the teaching.

an5.73:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhu, bhikkhu yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena paresaṃ deseti.
an5.73:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant teaches Dhamma in detail to others as they learned and memorized it.

an5.73:3.2.pli: So tāya dhammapaññattiyā divasaṃ atināmeti, riñcati paṭisallānaṃ, nānuyuñjati ajjhattaṃ cetosamathaṃ.
an5.73:3.2.eng: They spend too much time advocating that teaching. They neglect retreat, and are not committed to internal serenity of heart.

an5.73:3.3.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhu: ‘bhikkhu paññattibahulo, no dhammavihārī’.
an5.73:3.3.eng: That mendicant is called one who advocates a lot, not one who lives by the teaching.

an5.73:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhu, bhikkhu yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena sajjhāyaṃ karoti.
an5.73:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant rehearses the teaching in detail as they learned and memorized it.

an5.73:4.2.pli: So tena sajjhāyena divasaṃ atināmeti, riñcati paṭisallānaṃ, nānuyuñjati ajjhattaṃ cetosamathaṃ.
an5.73:4.2.eng: They spend too much time reciting that teaching. They neglect retreat, and are not committed to internal serenity of heart.

an5.73:4.3.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhu: ‘bhikkhu sajjhāyabahulo, no dhammavihārī’.
an5.73:4.3.eng: That mendicant is called one who rehearses a lot, not one who lives by the teaching.

an5.73:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhu, bhikkhu yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati.
an5.73:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant thinks about and considers the teaching in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it.

an5.73:5.2.pli: So tehi dhammavitakkehi divasaṃ atināmeti, riñcati paṭisallānaṃ, nānuyuñjati ajjhattaṃ cetosamathaṃ.
an5.73:5.2.eng: They spend too much time thinking about that teaching. They neglect retreat, and are not committed to internal serenity of heart.

an5.73:5.3.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhu: ‘bhikkhu vitakkabahulo, no dhammavihārī’.
an5.73:5.3.eng: That mendicant is called one who thinks a lot, not one who lives by the teaching.

an5.73:6.1.eng: Take a mendicant who memorizes the teaching—

an5.73:6.2.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ.
an5.73:6.2.eng: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.

an5.73:6.3.pli: So tāya dhammapariyattiyā na divasaṃ atināmeti, nāpi riñcati paṭisallānaṃ, anuyuñjati ajjhattaṃ cetosamathaṃ.
an5.73:6.3.eng: They don’t spend too much time studying that teaching. They don’t neglect retreat, and they’re committed to internal serenity of heart.

an5.73:6.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, bhikkhu dhammavihārī hoti.
an5.73:6.4.eng: That’s how a mendicant is one who lives by the teaching.

an5.73:7.1.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhu, desito mayā pariyattibahulo, desito paññattibahulo, desito sajjhāyabahulo, desito vitakkabahulo, desito dhammavihārī.
an5.73:7.1.eng: So, mendicant, I’ve taught you the one who studies a lot, the one who advocates a lot, the one who rehearses a lot, the one who thinks a lot, and the one who lives by the teaching.

an5.73:7.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhu, satthārā karaṇīyaṃ sāvakānaṃ hitesinā anukampakena anukampaṃ upādāya, kataṃ vo taṃ mayā.
an5.73:7.2.eng: Out of sympathy, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.

an5.73:7.3.pli: Etāni, bhikkhu, rukkhamūlāni, etāni suññāgārāni. Jhāyatha, bhikkhu, mā pamādattha, mā pacchā vippaṭisārino ahuvattha. Ayaṃ vo amhākaṃ anusāsanī”ti.
an5.73:7.3.eng: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, mendicant! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”

an5.74:0.3.eng: One Who Lives by the Teaching (2nd)

an5.74:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an5.74:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an5.74:1.2.eng: “Sir, they speak of ‘one who lives by the teaching’.

an5.74:1.3.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhu dhammavihārī hotī”ti?
an5.74:1.3.eng: How is a mendicant who lives by the teaching defined?”

an5.74:2.1.eng: “Mendicant, take a mendicant who memorizes the teaching—

an5.74:2.2.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ;
an5.74:2.2.eng: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.

an5.74:2.3.eng: But they don’t understand the higher meaning.

an5.74:2.4.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhu: ‘bhikkhu pariyattibahulo, no dhammavihārī’.
an5.74:2.4.eng: That mendicant is called one who studies a lot, not one who lives by the teaching.

an5.74:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhu, bhikkhu yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena paresaṃ deseti, uttari cassa paññāya atthaṃ nappajānāti.
an5.74:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant teaches Dhamma in detail to others as they learned and memorized it. But they don’t understand the higher meaning.

an5.74:3.2.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhu: ‘bhikkhu paññattibahulo, no dhammavihārī’.
an5.74:3.2.eng: That mendicant is called one who advocates a lot, not one who lives by the teaching.

an5.74:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhu, bhikkhu yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena sajjhāyaṃ karoti, uttari cassa paññāya atthaṃ nappajānāti.
an5.74:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant rehearses the teaching in detail as they learned and memorized it. But they don’t understand the higher meaning.

an5.74:4.2.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhu: ‘bhikkhu sajjhāyabahulo, no dhammavihārī’.
an5.74:4.2.eng: That mendicant is called one who rehearses a lot, not one who lives by the teaching.

an5.74:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhu, bhikkhu yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati, uttari cassa paññāya atthaṃ nappajānāti.
an5.74:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant thinks about and considers the teaching in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it. But they don’t understand the higher meaning.

an5.74:5.2.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhu: ‘bhikkhu vitakkabahulo, no dhammavihārī’.
an5.74:5.2.eng: That mendicant is called one who thinks a lot, not one who lives by the teaching.

an5.74:6.1.eng: Take a mendicant who memorizes the teaching—

an5.74:6.2.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ;
an5.74:6.2.eng: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.

an5.74:6.3.eng: And they do understand the higher meaning.

an5.74:6.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, bhikkhu dhammavihārī hoti.
an5.74:6.4.eng: That’s how a mendicant is one who lives by the teaching.

an5.74:7.1.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhu, desito mayā pariyattibahulo, desito paññattibahulo, desito sajjhāyabahulo, desito vitakkabahulo, desito dhammavihārī.
an5.74:7.1.eng: So, mendicant, I’ve taught you the one who studies a lot, the one who advocates a lot, the one who rehearses a lot, the one who thinks a lot, and the one who lives by the teaching.

an5.74:7.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhu, satthārā karaṇīyaṃ sāvakānaṃ hitesinā anukampakena anukampaṃ upādāya, kataṃ vo taṃ mayā.
an5.74:7.2.eng: Out of sympathy, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.

an5.74:7.3.pli: Etāni, bhikkhu, rukkhamūlāni, etāni suññāgārāni. Jhāyatha bhikkhu, mā pamādattha, mā pacchā vippaṭisārino ahuvattha. Ayaṃ vo amhākaṃ anusāsanī”ti.
an5.74:7.3.eng: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, mendicant! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”
